Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
translation_text.mn77:6.53: That’s how the Jain Ñātika is not honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. On the contrary, his disciples, not honoring and respecting him, don’t remain loyal to him.
translation_text.mn77:6.54: Rather, he’s reviled, and rightly so.’
translation_text.mn77:6.56: ‘This ascetic Gotama leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people.
translation_text.mn77:6.57: He’s honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. And his disciples, honoring and respecting him, remain loyal to him.
translation_text.mn77:6.58: Once it so happened that he was teaching an assembly of many hundreds.
translation_text.mn77:6.59: Then one of his disciples cleared their throat.
translation_text.mn77:6.60: And one of their spiritual companions nudged them with their knee, to indicate,
translation_text.mn77:6.61: “Hush, venerable, don’t make sound! Our teacher, the Blessed One, is teaching!”
translation_text.mn77:6.62: While the ascetic Gotama is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats.
translation_text.mn77:6.63: That large crowd is poised expectantly at the ready, thinking,
translation_text.mn77:6.64: “Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.”
translation_text.mn77:6.65: It’s like when there’s a person at the crossroads pressing out pure dwarf-bee honey,
translation_text.mn77:6.66: and a large crowd is poised expectantly at the ready.
translation_text.mn77:6.67: In the same way, while the ascetic Gotama is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats.
translation_text.mn77:6.68: That large crowd is poised expectantly at the ready, thinking,
translation_text.mn77:6.69: “Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.”
translation_text.mn77:6.70: Even when disciples of the ascetic Gotama, having clashed with their spiritual companions, disavow the training and return to a lesser life, they speak only praise of the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. They blame only themselves, not others: “We were unlucky, we had little merit. For even after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we weren’t able to practice for life the perfectly full and pure spiritual life.”
translation_text.mn77:6.71: They become monastery workers or lay followers, and they proceed having undertaken the five precepts.
translation_text.mn77:6.72: That’s how the ascetic Gotama is honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. And that’s how his disciples, honoring and respecting him, remain loyal to him.’”
translation_text.mn77:7.1: “But Udāyī, how many qualities do you see in me, because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me?”
translation_text.mn77:8.1: “Sir, I see five such qualities in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.3: The Buddha eats little and praises eating little.
translation_text.mn77:8.4: This is the first such quality I see in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.5: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.
translation_text.mn77:8.6: This is the second such quality I see in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.7: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of almsfood, and praises such contentment.
translation_text.mn77:8.8: This is the third such quality I see in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.9: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of lodging, and praises such contentment.
translation_text.mn77:8.10: This is the fourth such quality I see in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.11: Furthermore, the Buddha is secluded, and praises seclusion.
translation_text.mn77:8.12: This is the fifth such quality I see in the Buddha.
translation_text.mn77:8.13: These are the five qualities I see in the Buddha, because of which his disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate him; and honoring and respecting him, they remain loyal to him.”
translation_text.mn77:9.1: “Suppose, Udāyī, my disciples were loyal to me because I eat little. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat a tumbler of food, or half a tumbler; they eat a wood-apple, or half a wood-apple.
translation_text.mn77:9.2: But sometimes I even eat this bowl full to the brim, or even more.
translation_text.mn77:9.3: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I eat little, then those disciples who eat even less would not be loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:9.4: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe. Well, there are disciples of mine who have rag robes, wearing shabby robes. They gather scraps from charnel grounds, rubbish dumps, and shops, make them into a patchwork robe and wear it.
translation_text.mn77:9.5: But sometimes I wear robes offered by householders that are strong, yet next to which bottle-gourd down is coarse.
translation_text.mn77:9.6: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe, then those disciples who wear rag robes would not be loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:9.7: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, happy to eat whatever they glean. When they’ve entered an inhabited area, they don’t consent when invited to sit down.
translation_text.mn77:9.8: But sometimes I even eat by invitation boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces.
translation_text.mn77:9.9: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood, then those disciples who eat only almsfood would not be loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:9.10: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging. Well, there are disciples of mine who stay at the root of a tree, in the open air. For eight months they don’t go under a roof.
translation_text.mn77:9.11: But sometimes I even stay in bungalows, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with doors fastened and windows shuttered.
translation_text.mn77:9.12: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging, then those disciples who stay at the root of a tree would not be loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:9.13: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m secluded and I praise seclusion. Well, there are disciples of mine who live in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. Having ventured deep into remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest, they live there, coming down to the midst of the Saṅgha each fortnight for the recitation of the monastic code.
translation_text.mn77:9.14: But sometimes I live crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their chief ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples.
translation_text.mn77:9.15: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m secluded and praise seclusion, then those disciples who live in the wilderness would not be loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:9.16: So, Udāyī, it’s not because of these five qualities that my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:10.1: There are five other qualities because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:10.3: Firstly, my disciples esteem me for the higher ethics:
translation_text.mn77:10.4: ‘The ascetic Gotama is ethical. He possesses the entire spectrum of ethical conduct to the highest degree.’
translation_text.mn77:11.2: this is the first quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:12.1: Furthermore, my disciples esteem me for my excellent knowledge and vision:
translation_text.mn77:12.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama only claims to know when he does in fact know.
translation_text.mn77:12.3: He only claims to see when he really does see.
translation_text.mn77:12.4: He teaches based on direct knowledge, not without direct knowledge.
translation_text.mn77:12.5: He teaches based on reason, not without reason.
translation_text.mn77:12.6: He teaches with a demonstrable basis, not without it.’
translation_text.mn77:12.12: this is the second quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:13.1: Furthermore, my disciples esteem me for my higher wisdom:
translation_text.mn77:13.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama is wise. He possesses the entire spectrum of wisdom to the highest degree.
translation_text.mn77:13.3: It’s not possible that he would fail to foresee grounds for future criticism, or to legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up.’
translation_text.mn77:13.5: Would my disciples, knowing and seeing this, break in and interrupt me?”
translation_text.mn77:13.7: “That’s because I don’t expect to be instructed by my disciples.
translation_text.mn77:13.8: Invariably, my disciples expect instruction from me.
translation_text.mn77:13.13: this is the third quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:14.1: Furthermore, my disciples come to me and ask how the noble truth of suffering applies to the suffering in which they are swamped and mired. And I provide them with a satisfying answer to their question.
translation_text.mn77:14.2: They ask how the noble truths of the origin of suffering,
translation_text.mn77:14.4: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering apply to the suffering  in which they are swamped and mired. And I provide them with satisfying answers to their questions.
translation_text.mn77:14.11: this is the fourth quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:15.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
translation_text.mn77:15.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn77:15.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.mn77:15.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn77:15.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:16.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four right efforts.
translation_text.mn77:16.2: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.
translation_text.mn77:16.3: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.
translation_text.mn77:16.4: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.
translation_text.mn77:16.5: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn77:16.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:17.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four bases of psychic power.
translation_text.mn77:17.2: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.
translation_text.mn77:17.3: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.
translation_text.mn77:17.4: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.
translation_text.mn77:17.5: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.
translation_text.mn77:17.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:18.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the five faculties.
translation_text.mn77:18.2: It’s when a mendicant develops the faculties of faith,
translation_text.mn77:18.6: and wisdom, which lead to peace and awakening.
translation_text.mn77:18.7: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:19.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the five powers.
translation_text.mn77:19.2: It’s when a mendicant develops the powers of faith,
translation_text.mn77:19.6: and wisdom, which lead to peace and awakening.
translation_text.mn77:19.7: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:20.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the seven awakening factors.
translation_text.mn77:20.2: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,
translation_text.mn77:20.8: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
translation_text.mn77:20.9: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:21.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.mn77:21.2: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn77:21.3: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:22.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the eight liberations.
translation_text.mn77:22.2: Having physical form, they see forms.
translation_text.mn77:22.4: Not perceiving form internally, they see forms externally.
translation_text.mn77:22.8: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.mn77:22.10: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.mn77:22.12: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn77:22.14: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.mn77:22.16: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.mn77:22.18: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:23.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the eight dimensions of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.2: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.mn77:23.3: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.4: This is the first dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.5: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.mn77:23.6: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.7: This is the second dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.8: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.mn77:23.9: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.10: This is the third dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.11: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.mn77:23.12: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.13: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.14: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.15: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.16: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.17: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.18: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.19: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.20: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.21: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.22: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.23: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.24: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.25: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.26: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.27: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.28: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.29: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.30: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.31: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.mn77:23.32: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.mn77:23.33: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.mn77:23.34: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:24.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the ten universal dimensions of meditation.
translation_text.mn77:24.2: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.mn77:24.3: They perceive the meditation on universal water …
translation_text.mn77:24.11: the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.mn77:24.12: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:25.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four absorptions.
translation_text.mn77:25.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn77:25.3: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn77:25.4: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
translation_text.mn77:25.5: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn77:26.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn77:26.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn77:26.3: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time.
translation_text.mn77:26.4: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
translation_text.mn77:26.5: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn77:27.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn77:27.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn77:27.3: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
translation_text.mn77:27.4: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn77:28.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn77:28.2: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn77:28.3: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
translation_text.mn77:28.4: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn77:28.5: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:29.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand this:
translation_text.mn77:29.2: ‘This body of mine is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
translation_text.mn77:29.3: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
translation_text.mn77:29.4: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent and clear, endowed with all good qualities.
translation_text.mn77:29.5: And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.
translation_text.mn77:29.6: And a person with clear eyes were to take it in their hand and check it:
translation_text.mn77:29.7: ‘This beryl gem is naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent and clear, endowed with all good qualities.
translation_text.mn77:29.8: And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’
translation_text.mn77:29.9: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand this:
translation_text.mn77:29.10: ‘This body of mine is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
translation_text.mn77:29.11: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
translation_text.mn77:29.12: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:30.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
translation_text.mn77:30.2: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
translation_text.mn77:30.4: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
translation_text.mn77:30.5: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
translation_text.mn77:30.7: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
translation_text.mn77:30.8: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.
translation_text.mn77:30.10: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
translation_text.mn77:30.11: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
translation_text.mn77:30.12: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:31.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn77:31.2: Suppose a deft potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
translation_text.mn77:31.3: Or suppose a deft ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
translation_text.mn77:31.4: Or suppose a deft goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
translation_text.mn77:31.5: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power …
translation_text.mn77:31.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:32.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.mn77:32.2: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
translation_text.mn77:32.3: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.mn77:32.4: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:33.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.
translation_text.mn77:33.2: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
translation_text.mn77:33.3: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’;
translation_text.mn77:33.4: mind with hate as ‘mind with hate’,
translation_text.mn77:33.5: and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate’;
translation_text.mn77:33.6: mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion’,
translation_text.mn77:33.7: and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion’;
translation_text.mn77:33.12: mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme’,
translation_text.mn77:33.13: and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme’;
translation_text.mn77:33.14: mind immersed in samādhi as ‘mind immersed in samādhi’,
translation_text.mn77:33.15: and mind not immersed in samādhi as ‘mind not immersed in samādhi’;
translation_text.mn77:33.18: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot’, and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots’.
translation_text.mn77:33.19: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind …
translation_text.mn77:33.36: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:34.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn77:34.2: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
translation_text.mn77:34.3: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives.
translation_text.mn77:34.4: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:35.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn77:35.2: Suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
translation_text.mn77:35.3: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn …
translation_text.mn77:35.4: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:36.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn77:36.2: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. They’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
translation_text.mn77:36.3: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn77:36.4: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
translation_text.mn77:37.1: This is the fifth quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
translation_text.mn77:38.1: These are the five qualities because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.”
translation_text.mn77:38.2: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn77:38.3: Satisfied, the wanderer Sakuludāyī approved what the Buddha said.
